channel.title: tastytrade: Market Measures
channel.description: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Tom and Bat present research on the market, examining probabilities, volatility, strategies, and more.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade
channel.itunes:summary: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.
channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: Tail Risk with Strangles
item.description:
Join Tom and Tony as they look at the tail risk that comes with trading strangles on SPY and when these events are most likely to occur.

16 delta strangles on SPY have an extremely high win rate, at roughly 80%, but they are still exposed to sizable tail risk.

How likely is it to see losers of varying magnitude, and just how bad can these losers be? Tune in to find out!

item.title: The Risk of Getting Big
item.description:
When trading options, it is crucial to understand the risk you carry when selling premium...over-allocating an options portfolio is a non-issue 80 to 90% of the time but a critical issue during market panics. 

The goal of a successful options trader is to “stay in business”. The variable that will most affect this is the portfolio exposure in the dull markets leading up to a crash.

item.title: Different Ways to Trade Yields
item.description: At the most recent FOMC meeting, Powell announced that short term rates will remain at 0%. Even so, market participants do worry about the potential of a rate hike in the future.If you want to trade interest rate products, there are a few ways to trade them, depending on your account size and desire for capital efficiency.

item.title: What Does It Take to Crush Volatility?
item.description:
Even though implied volatility may be inversely correlated to the direction of the market, the underlying reason that causes IV to change is actual moves vs expected moves, and the fear of future actual moves being larger than currently priced.

This played out perfectly in the 2020 selloff...where the VIX continued to expand as the down days got worse, but as soon as we saw a 2% down day when a 4% move was expected, VIX immediately collapsed.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: How Does a Daily 2% Move Impact the VIX?
item.description: tastytrade looks at how the same size moves in the SPX can impact VIX in different ways, depending on where VIX started.This week we have seen higher levels of volatility market-wide, with SPY, QQQ, and IWM hitting their highest IV levels since May. We analyzed 2% or greater down moves in the SPX from 1990 to present to see why we saw such a large increase, on a percent basis, in the VIX this week.VIX moves most aggressively at low levels, which is why we often say don’t sell in low IV environments.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: Large Consecutive Down Days
item.description:
Streaks of large down days are quite uncommon, with only 31 streaks of 3 or more 1% down moves in the SPX since 1993, looking at ~8000 trading days of data. 

The biggest move in a streak tends to be the third day, with an average SPX move of nearly -3% coupled with an expansion of 3 points in the VIX.

item.title: Do Win Rates of Sectors Differ?
item.description:
The theoretical win rate for a 16 delta strangle should be just over 68%, but our previous studies have shown that the win rate comes in higher than that. Do the major sectors follow this trend?

tastytrade looks at the 3 largest companies in the energy, technology, financials, healthcare, and utilities sector ETFs to see how their win rates compare.

Join Tony and TP as they discuss win rates across sectors and what the relationship is between win rate, IV, and premium.

item.title: Diversifying by Underlying
item.description: Whether adopting an equity, option, or hybrid portfolio, diversifying a portfolio according to underlying is crucial. Underlying diversification is especially important when there is short premium concentration in a portfolio, as a portfolio can easily be wiped out when multiple positions incur tail losses simultaneously. Join Tom and TP as they use some statistics to demonstrate this concept.

item.title: Are All Strangles Created Equal?
item.description: The theoretical win rate for a 16 delta strangle should be just over 68%, but our previous studies have shown that the win rate comes in higher than that. Does this hold true for all stocks? We look at AT&T, Pfizer, Apple, Microsoft, and Tesla to see how their win rates compare to the benchmarks of SPY and IWM.

item.title: Trading Options on Crypto Stock
item.description:
Because a semi-strong correlation exists between BLOK and Bitcoin, one may consider using BLOK options as a proxy for Bitcoin options. Due to its IV, liquidity, and price, BLOK is accessible to most account sizes.

Comparing the theoretical risk between a BLOK strangle and a hypothetical Bitcoin strangle, one BLOK strangle currently carries roughly 1/100th the risk of one Bitcoin strangle.

item.title: Historical Crypto Drawdowns
item.description: Crypto is becoming such a large asset class that retail traders need to understand what exposure to crypto in their portfolio can lead to over the short and long term.Crypto tends to have larger moves to both the upside and downside, but over the past year, it's continued to trend higher...

item.title: Higher Risk, Higher Reward
item.description:
Selling strangles has been, on average, profitable in all IV environments. However, lower IV periods tend to be less profitable because credits are lower and the P/L % of credit is lower.

Based on the results from the backtest in this study, the average dollar P/L of a SPY strangle could be 4x to 5x higher when the VIX is above 20, compared to lower IVs when normalizing for strangle delta and price of the underlying.

item.title: Seasonality of Discretionary Stocks
item.description:
Seasonality means seeing predictable changes that occur at specific time intervals each year. Corporations and investors look to use seasonality to their advantage when making decisions. But does it actually help investors?

Retail sales see seasonal moves, increasing near the holiday periods and then decreasing afterwards. But these sales numbers do not directly translate into an increase in market price.

item.title: NFTs and ETH's Relationship
item.description:
NFTs are gaining popularity at a rapid pace as one of the primary digital assets, with $830 million in daily sales on Wednesday, September 1st. This is up from $200 million in daily sales from August 1st. 

Most NFTs are part of the Ethereum blockchain--therefore, Ethereum (ETH) is also the most popular currency used to purchase NFTs.

As an effect, ETH has seen its price pushing back towards all-time highs from the July lows.

item.title: The St Petersburg Paradox
item.description:
When deciding on a trade, there is no right or wrong trade...but rather a given risk with a given potential payout with some probability. 

Prices change constantly with the market’s perception of risk and desire for return.

At the end of the day, only you can decide what trade is right for you, since you are the only relevant party that will either benefit or lose from the trade.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: When deciding on a trade, there is no right or wrong trade...but rather a given risk with a given potential payout with some probability. Prices change constantly with the market’s perception of risk and desire for return. At the end of the day, o...
item.content:encoded:
When deciding on a trade, there is no right or wrong trade...but rather a given risk with a given potential payout with some probability. 

Prices change constantly with the market’s perception of risk and desire for return.

At the end of the day, only you can decide what trade is right for you, since you are the only relevant party that will either benefit or lose from the trade.

item.title: The St Petersburg Paradox
item.description:
When deciding on a trade, there is no right or wrong trade...but rather a given risk with a given potential payout with some probability. 

Prices change constantly with the market’s perception of risk and desire for return.

At the end of the day, only you can decide what trade is right for you, since you are the only relevant party that will either benefit or lose from the trade.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

Prices change constantly with the market’s perception of risk and desire for return.

At the end of the day, only you can decide what trade is right for you, since you are the only relevant party that will either benefit or lose from the trade.

item.title: Drawdowns on a 45-day Cycle
item.description: tastytrade often looks at trading 45-day cycles and continually putting on new positions in the next cycle. Within these cycles however, what kind of drawdowns can we expect? Median drawdowns vary across ETFs, but as the size of historical drawdowns increase, so do the current implied volatilities.Implied volatility allows traders to get a good estimate about what kind of moves the market is expecting, but more often than not, the expectations are less than the actual move.

item.title: Core Differences: Stocks & ETFs
item.description: On average, ETFs carry lower IVs than individual stocks, and therefore ETFs tend to be less risky to trade. This is due to most ETFs being heavily diversified by default. However, when placing a trade, the implied volatility is the final determinant of the asset’s risk: an ETF and stock that have the same IV both carry identical risk profiles at that point in time. Therefore, whether an underlying is a stock or ETF is irrelevant. The IV of the underlying is what determines the risk.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
